ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: Good mindset

I gained a comprehensive understanding of the Aristotelian and Platonic philosophies, Greek tragedies of the Attic tradition, as well as important ideas from the likes of Schopenhauer, Kierkegaard, Nagel, Williams, and contemporary contributors to the Aristotelian ethical tradition. More importantly than the content, however, the dynamic, deeply thought-provoking and engaging discussions during class taught me how to think, write, question like a philosopher. I will take what I have learned in this class with me for the rest of Yale and beyond.
A good gateway for a study of analytic ethics.
Stuff about Aristotelian Ethics, and how to analytically recontruct arguments of difficult texts
I learned a lot about Aristotles view on happiness and got to explore different works of tragic literature.
Layout out philosophical arguments in logical format. Thinking through my positions and arguments systematically, analyzing a subject through the lens of multiple philosophical frameworks.
I learned a lot about the general way of thinking about life and what these topics entail in depth.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: Great.

The course's primary strengths are the dynamically compiled syllabus with a diverse selection of complementary works, the excellent instruction and guidance of Professor Charles, and the engaging class environment which fostered challenging group discussions. As far as weaknesses, I can only say that at times I felt as though the readings went over my head--that said, Professor Charles was always available to meet after class or at office hours, and did a great job at clearing up any confusion.

The Aristotelian and Neo-Aristotelian weeks were simply much more engaging (despite my own preferences) than the weeks we focused on theatre or aesthetic theory, as the class was strongest when we discussed topics that were of personal interest to Professor Charles. The class really depends on Professor Charles seminar leadership. It is truly spectacular. His ability to connect every comment to the strands of argument he wants to pursue is uncanny. That said, when he didnt have a clear argument to put forward we did have more of a tendency to sputter.
I think the course would benefit from a more robust intro to the Aristotelian background.
I wouldve liked to have had a set list of readings rather than deciding what we would read along the course. But I enjoyed reading literature in a philosophy course.

The course was very engaging and the focus on class discussion and prepared questions meant that everyone came to class with interesting thoughts and observations. I also enjoyed the freedom given to us in terms of choosing our paper topics.
Content and discussions.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes.

Yes, absolutely. Apart from becoming well-versed in the Attic and Ancient Greek philosophical traditions--as well as becoming acquainted with various other philosophical ideas over the course of the semester--what this class teaches best is how ask the right questions, construct a compelling argument, and think deeply about philosophical questions in a way that is important for both academic discourse and living a good life.

If you like in-depth discussions about the nature of happiness and how quickly tragedy can ruin everything, this class is for you! A really interesting class focused on how various theories of human happiness hold up in tragic circumstances.

Absolutely. Take any class with Professor Charles that you can. He is extraordinarily kind, and he invests a lot of time into his students. He reworked the schedule multiple times and routinely offered extra office hours to help us in the course. He is very receptive to feedback, and you can tell how much he cares about the course. Not to mention that he also a world expert on Aristotle.

Absolutely! This was, in my opinion, the best philosophy class that I've taken. We discuss not just the texts but also trying to fit the texts within a broader concept scope and trying to answer fundamental questions about happiness and what makes life worth living.

I think the course is fantastic for students of contemporary philosophy, especially those interested in ethics or more broadly the analytic school. That said I dont think the course is particularly well suited to students of theatre or aesthetics, or even students who are interested in less Aristotelian notions of ethics.
Would 100% recommend any course with Prof. David Charles, if you are in any field remotely related to Philosophy at all. At least take one course with him
Yes, it was a very good philosophy course.
Yes, I would highly recommend it.
Yes
